thread.title: Domestic violence division disbanded
thread.title_full: Domestic violence division disbanded | Albuquerque Journal News

author: Colleen Heild / Journal Investigative Reporter
title: Domestic violence division disbanded
text:
The Bernalillo County District Attorney’s Office is disbanding its long-standing felony domestic violence division, merging it with its violent crimes unit after the resignation of a deputy district attorney who oversaw such prosecutions.
In a news release, the DA’s Office called the merger of the two divisions “exciting” and a reaffirmation of its “commitment to hold domestic violence offenders accountable.”
“We feel this is a definite plus for the community and victims of domestic violence, who will be given every bit as much of a priority now as they have in the past,” District Attorney Kari Brandenburg was Quote: d as saying in the news release, issued hours after the Journal asked questions about the change.
The move came as the chief of the division, Deputy District Attorney Edna Sprague, resigned to join a private law firm.
According to the news release, combining the two divisions “simply formalizes the process and provides additional resources to both divisions.”
Now two more DA investigators can assist with domestic violence cases, the news release said. Currently, the division has only one investigator.
“Additionally, more attorneys will share the difficult and emotional caseload of our domestic violence cases,” the news release said. The paralegal staff will double in size, and “our victim advocates will receive some reprieve from the difficulty of such emotional cases.”
Brandenburg said in the news release that the felony domestic violence division has had a large increase in criminal trials and that vacancies have been difficult to fill since a state Supreme Court order this year aimed at speeding up criminal felony cases in Bernalillo County.
Ann Badway, who was chief of the division from about 1995 to 2004, said the felony domestic violence division was created by then-District Attorney Bob Schwartz, who served eight years as DA, from 1988 to 1996.
“It was almost like a pet project with him. And you know what? We did a heck of a job,” Badway said Wednesday. “I think having that specialized unit had an incredibly positive impact on the community. We educated whole lot of folks. It was a heck of a program.”
Badway, who now lives in Florida, headed the division from 1996 to 2004. She said merging the two divisions would be beneficial for the sharing of the talent and expertise.
“But I thought that when Bob Schwartz started that division, I thought it made a significant impact in the community’s awareness as well as law enforcement,” she said.
She said domestic violence cases are “very unique, and can be very challenging, and it took someone who really wanted to take on that challenge of that type of case.”
“These are crimes that are often kept behind the closed front door of someone’s home,” Badway said.
Kayla Anderson, DA spokeswoman, said incoming domestic violence cases will be spread out among attorneys in the violent crimes division. The felony domestic violence division brought 249 indictments in the first nine months of this year, compared with 450 indictments in the violent crimes division for the same period.
Since the merger, the violent crimes division has gone from 13 lawyers to 21.
